column12: Title
column13: Abstract
column15: Inventors

column12: Intervertebral disc replacement
column13: An intervertebral disc prosthesis in a preferred embodiment has a matrix of bioincorporable fabric, and a nuclear core centrally mixed into the matrix. The core is formed by impregnating the fabric substrate centrally with a polymer, preferably of liquid form that cures into a viscoelastic solid, in which each component—polymer and fabric—reinforces the other against tearing, shearing and weakening under stress. The core is a hybrid composite adapted for elastic deformation centrally of the matrix, in which the polymer is mixed with the fabric, and is surrounded by the outer bioincorporable fabric margin of the matrix. In another embodiment, the nuclear core is separated from an outer sheath of the bioincorporable fabric by an intermediate ligament encasement that surrounds the purely polymeric core In either embodiment, each edge of the outer fabric that interfaces a vertebral end plate is impregnated with an agent to stimulate osseus incorporation and anchoring. An adjunct anchoring system with penetration of bone of adjacent vertebra may be used to for attachment until and after bioincorporation occurs.
column15: DICKMAN CURTIS A

The core is a hybrid composite adapted for elastic deformation centrally of the matrix, in which the polymer is mixed with the fabric, and is surrounded by the outer bioincorporable fabric margin of the matrix. In another embodiment, the nuclear core is separated from an outer sheath of the bioincorporable fabric by an intermediate ligament encasement that surrounds the purely polymeric core In either embodiment, each edge of the outer fabric that interfaces a vertebral end plate is impregnated with an agent to stimulate osseus incorporation and anchoring. An adjunct anchoring system with penetration of bone of adjacent vertebra may be used to for attachment until and after bioincorporation occurs.

column12: Lift mechanism for lifting refuse containers
column13: A lift mechanism for use with a refuse collection vehicle for lifting and dumping refuse carts. The device includes a frame which is adapted for mounting on a refuse collection vehicle and a pan assembly which is adapted to engage refuse carts. A pair of guide arms provided which have a first end pivotally connected to a frame and a second end which is pivotally connected to the pan assembly. A first actuator arm is provided having a first end connected to the frame and a second end connected to a reciprocating actuator. A pair of second actuator arms is provided having a first end connected to a frame and having a second end connected to the pan assembly. A connecting arm is pivotally connected at a first end to a second end of the first actuator arms and at a second end to the second actuator arms at a location between the first end and second end of the second actuator arms. The connecting arm provides corresponding movement of the second actuator arm in response to movement of first actuator arm. The reciprocating actuator moves the pan assembly through the first actuator arms, the connecting arm, and the second actuator arms between a receiving position for engaging the refuse cart and a dumping position for emptying the refuse cart.
column15: HUNTOON RUSSELL CURTIS;;DICKMAN THOMAS FREDERICK
column16: OTTO INDUSTRIES NORTH AMERICA INC (2008-03-14);;AUTOMATED REFUSE EQUIPMENT INC (1996-07-08)

column12: Spinal plating and intervertebral support systems and methods
column13: A plating system for stabilizing at least one level of the spinal column includes a plate member having a first portion with a bottom surface extending between opposite sides of the plate member. The bottom surface is positionable extradiscally along first and second vertebrae for engagement of the plate member thereto. A second portion of the plate member extends from one side of the first portion and away from the second side of the first portion. The second portion is received in the disc space between the first and second vertebrae and intradiscally engageable to at least one of the first and second vertebra.
column15: LEHUEC JEAN-CHARLES;;DICKMAN CURTIS A;;ANDERSON KENT

column12: SPINAL PLATING AND INTERVERTEBRAL SUPPORT SYSTEMS AND METHODS
column13: A plating system (40, 240) for stabilizing at least one level of the spinal column includes a plate member (60, 260) having a first portion (70, 270) with a bottom surface (82, 282) extending between opposite sides of the plate member (60, 260). The bottom surface (82, 282) is positionable extradiscally along first and second vertebrae for engagement of the plate member (60, 260) thereto. A second portion (90, 290) of the plate member (60, 260) extends from one side of the first portion (70, 270) and away from the second side of the first portion (70, 270). The second portion (90, 290) is received in the disc space between the first and second vertebrae and intradiscally engageable to at least one of the first and second vertebra.

column12: SYSTEM FÜR DIE VORDERVERPLATTUNG DER WIRBELSÄULE
column13: Systems and methods for stabilizing the spine are provided. For stabilizing the L5-S1 junction, the system includes a plate that has a generally triangular shape with an upper node and a pair of lower nodes. The upper node has a hole through the plate to receive a screw for passage into the L5 vertebra. The lower nodes each include a hole through the plate to receive screws for passage into the S1 vertebra. The system further includes a plate having a retaining element for preventing backout of screws inserted through the plate. Instruments and methods for attaching the plate to the spinal column are also provided.
column15: LEHEUC JEAN-CHARLES;;JOSSE LOIC;;LIU MINGYAN;;LANGE ERIC;;DICKMAN CURTIS

column12: Plating system for stabilizing a bony segment
column13: A plating system for stabilization of a bony segment includes a plate engageable to at least first and second bony elements. For spinal stabilization, the plate is attached at least to first and second vertebrae with at least one bone fastener in each vertebra. Retaining members are attachable to the plate to prevent the bone fasteners from backing out of the plate. One retaining member is a variable retaining member that allows the bone fasteners to toggle in the plate without interference. A second retaining member is a fixed retaining member that fixes the bone fasteners relative to the plate.
column15: LEHUEC JEAN-CHARLES;;DICKMAN CURTIS A;;LIU MINGYAN;;JOSSE LOIC;;LANGE ERIC C

column12: ANTERIOR PLATING SYSTEM AND METHOD
column13: Systems and methods for stabilizing the spine are provided. For stabilizing the L5-S1 junction, the system includes a plate (7) that has a generally triangular shape with an upper node (8a) and a pair of lower nodes (9a, 10a). The upper node (8a) has a hole (8) through the plate (7) to receive a screw (11) for passage into the L5 vertebra. The lower nodes (9a, 10a) each include a hole (9,10) through the plate (7) to receive screws (12, 13) for passage into the S1 vertebra. The system further includes a plate (7) having a retaining element (32) for preventing backout of screws inserted through the plate (9). Instruments and methods for attaching the plate to the spinal column are also provided.
column15: LEHEUC JEAN-CHARLES;;JOSSE LOIC;;LIU MINGYAN;;LANGE ERIC C;;DICKMAN CURTIS A

column12: PLATING SYSTEM FOR STABILIZING A BONY SEGMENT
column13: A plating system for stabilization of a bony segment includes a plate engageable to at least first and second bony elements. For spinal stabilization, the plate is attached at least to first and second vertebrae with at least one bone fastener in each vertebra. Retaining members are attachable to the plate to prevent the bone fasteners from backing out of the plate. One retaining member has apertures over the bone plateholes and allows the bone fasteners to pivot in the plate. A second retaining member fixes the bone fasteners erlative to the plate by means of engagement members which engage the tool engagement recesses of the bone fasteners.
